The parasite, or dines-out, of later times, had no resemblance to the client of the republic. He was no inore than one of many in the train of a rich man, o‘r of as many rich men as he could get attached to in that mean capacity. The old relation of ‘patronus' and ‘cliens' so far as we can understand it, was simple and natural. The other was · the mere refuge of poverty, preferring the bread of idleness and a false tangue to a life of honest labor and the rewards of an indepen- dent mind. The student will only be misled if, following some of the commentatore, he looks upon the latter condition as but another phase of the former. The old institution died out with the republic to which it belonged; the modern practice was the fruit of human corruption, and has its analogies in all ages of society, such as is called civiiized.
